legal_context.imprisonment_conditions: Held in house of prévôt at St Dié for over 2 years (June 1606 - August 1608). Prévôt complained of danger to his family and heavy costs. Boy showed himself 'strongly devoted to devotion and piety' during custody, prayed morning and night, took holy water from church daily. Prévôt raised him among his own children.

extraction_metadata.notes: This is an unusual case - a 10-year-old boy accused of witchcraft alongside another boy (Pieron). No formal witnesses testified against him; the case was based entirely on mutual accusations between the two boys and their confessions. The trial resulted in conflicting recommendations: Rémy wanted whipping and monastery placement, while the Change de Nancy recommended death. Ultimately the Duke showed mercy and the boy was released after 2+ years in custody. The case provides rich detail about children's experiences of poverty, labor, and the sabbat narrative. The judges challenged the truthfulness of the confession ('fables et mensonges'). Notable for extended custody period, ducal intervention, and ultimate release - very rare outcome. Trial documents span from June 1606 to November 1608.
